questions.text:
Which of the following enzymes are involved in gluconeogenesis? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Pyruvate carboxylase

B. Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxy kinase

C. Hexokinase

D. Pyruvate kinase

E. Glucose 6 phosphatase
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A and E only

 

Gluconeogenesis bypasses the three irreversible steps of glycolysis using four specific enzymes. From the given options, only two are actual gluconeogenic enzymes. Pyruvate carboxylase converts pyruvate to oxaloacetate in the mitochondria, requiring ATP and biotin as cofactor. This is the first step in bypassing the pyruvate kinase reaction. Glucose-6-phosphatase catalyzes the final step, converting glucose-6-phosphate to free glucose, which allows glucose release from liver and kidney cells. This enzyme is absent in muscle, explaining why muscle cannot contribute glucose to the bloodstream despite having glycogen stores.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (A, B and E only): "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" is not a real enzyme - this appears to be a nomenclature error. The actual gluconeogenic enzyme is phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK), which converts oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

 

Option B (B and C only): Neither enzyme participates in gluconeogenesis. "Phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" doesn't exist, and hexokinase catalyzes the forward glycolytic reaction (glucose → glucose-6-phosphate), consuming ATP rather than producing glucose.

 

Option D (A, B and C only): This includes both the non-existent "phosphoenol pyruvate kinase" and hexokinase, which is a glycolytic enzyme that would oppose gluconeogenesis by converting free glucose back to glucose-6-phosphate.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Among the listed enzymes, only pyruvate carboxylase and glucose-6-phosphatase are genuine gluconeogenic enzymes that help bypass the irreversible steps of glycolysis to synthesize glucose from non-carbohydrate precursors.

questions.text: Transparency of corneal endothelium is maintained by: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Keratan sulphate

 

  • Keratan sulfate is a key glycosaminoglycan present in the corneal endothelium. It plays a significant role in maintaining corneal transparency by regulating hydration, contributing to the structural integrity of the cornea, and preventing swelling, which could impair vision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparan sulfate: Heparan sulfate is a glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in the cornea, but its main role is in the basement membrane and Bowman's membrane, rather than the corneal endothelium. It plays a role in supporting the structure but is not the primary factor for endothelial transparency.

 

Option C. Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another glycosaminoglycan found in the cornea, but its primary role is not related to endothelial transparency. It contributes to the overall structure and function of the cornea but does not play a direct role in maintaining endothelial clarity.

 

Option D. Hyaluronic acid: Hyaluronic acid is essential for regulating hydration within the cornea, but its main role is in the corneal stroma, not the endothelium. It ensures the cornea remains transparent by preventing excessive swelling in the stromal tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref-Harper 31st e/pg. 602

questions.text: Which of these is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Insulinoma

 

The most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas is C) Insulinoma. These tumors are derived from the beta cells of the pancreas and are often associated with excessive insulin production, leading to hypoglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastrinoma:

  • Gastrinoma is a type of neuroendocrine tumor that primarily arises in the pancreas or duodenum.
  • It is associated with the overproduction of gastrin, which leads to excessive stomach acid production.
  • This condition can result in peptic ulcers, acid reflux, and gastrin-related symptoms (Zollinger-Ellison syndrome).
  • Gastrinomas are often associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1).

 

Option B. Somatostatinoma:

  • Somatostatinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that can occur in various parts of the gastrointestinal tract, including the pancreas.
  • These tumors produce excessive amounts of somatostatin, a hormone that inhibits the release of other hormones.
  • Symptoms may include diabetes mellitus, diarrhea, and gallstones.
  • Diagnosis and management often involve surgical removal and somatostatin analog medications.

 

Option D. VIPoma:

  • VIPoma, also known as Verner-Morrison syndrome, is a rare neuroendocrine tumor typically found in the pancreas.
  • It produces excessive amounts of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), leading to severe diarrhea and electrolyte imbalances.
  • Patients with VIPoma often experience "WDHA syndrome" (Watery Diarrhea, Hypokalemia, Achlorhydria).
  • Treatment involves addressing fluid and electrolyte imbalances and managing the tumor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insulinoma is the most common neuroendocrine tumor of the pancreas, arising from beta cells and frequently causing hypoglycemia due to excessive insulin production.

choices.text: Allergic Interstitial Nephritis
Urinary Tract Infection

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with follicular tonsillitis, for which antibiotics were prescribed. In a few days, the child developed flank pain and rash. Peripheral blood demonstrated eosinophilia, and urinalysis showed WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Allergic Interstitial Nephritis

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis (AIN), also known as drug-induced interstitial nephritis, is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by medications such as antibiotics (e.g., penicillins). The clinical presentation of AIN typically includes:

 

  • Recent medication use: In this case, antibiotics for follicular tonsillitis.
  • Flank pain and rash: These symptoms often develop a few days after starting the medication.
  • Eosinophilia: Elevated levels of eosinophils in peripheral blood are a hallmark of allergic reactions.
  • Urinalysis findings: Presence of white blood cell (WBC) casts in the urine indicates renal involvement.

 

The combination of these symptoms and laboratory findings strongly suggests allergic interstitial nephritis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pyelonephritis: Pyelonephritis is characterized by fever, unilateral flank pain, and urinary symptoms like dysuria. It is usually associated with bacterial infection, not with recent antibiotic use or eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Berger Disease (IgA Nephropathy): IgA nephropathy, or Berger disease, is a glomerulonephritis characterized by hematuria and sometimes proteinuria. It does not typically present with rash, eosinophilia, or WBC casts.

 

Option D. Urinary Tract Infection (UTI): A UTI would present with urinary symptoms such as dysuria, frequency, and urgency. It can also lead to pyelonephritis, but it does not typically cause eosinophilia or WBC casts in the absence of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allergic interstitial nephritis is characterized by recent medication use (such as antibiotics), flank pain, rash, eosinophilia, and WBC casts in urine. It is an immune-mediated condition commonly caused by drugs, particularly antibiotics.

questions.text: After the administration of phenylephrine, the depicted images reveal an observed alteration. What is the likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nodular episcleritis

 

Upon the application of phenylephrine, the superficial episcleral vessels lose their color, a phenomenon known as blanching. As a result, the likely conclusion is nodular episcleritis.

 

2.5% phenylephrine proves valuable in distinguishing between episcleritis and scleritis. This distinction arises from the fact that the vessels within the episclera lie close to the surface, making them susceptible to blanching. In contrast, in cases of scleritis, these vessels do not undergo such a color change.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nodular Scleritis: Scleritis involves deeper layers of the eye and is typically more painful. Vessels in scleritis do not blanch with phenylephrine due to their depth and the severity of inflammation.

 

Option C. Tenon's Cyst: This refers to a cystic lesion involving Tenon's capsule, not typically associated with the superficial vascular changes seen in episcleritis.

 

Option D. Nodular Phlycten: This is a small, nodular inflammatory lesion usually at the corneal limbus, often related to an immune response to bacterial proteins, particularly from staphylococcal or tubercular origins, not showing the same response to phenylephrine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Episcleritis can typically be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance and response to phenylephrine. The ability of phenylephrine to cause blanching of the inflamed episcleral vessels is a useful diagnostic tool, helping to differentiate episcleritis from more serious conditions like scleritis, where the inflammation involves deeper tissues and the vessels do not blanch.

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive vision loss. Imaging reveals an aneurysm compressing the optic chiasm. Which artery is most likely responsible for this compression? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior communicating artery

 

  • The likely cause of vision loss in this patient is an aneurysm of the anterior communicating artery, which is situated in close proximity to the optic chiasma.
  • The Circle of Willis, a major arterial connection between the internal carotid and vertebrobasilar systems, lies within the subarachnoid space surrounding the optic chiasma and infundibulum.
  • In cases of an anterior communicating artery aneurysm, which connects the right and left anterior cerebral arteries and is positioned anterior and superior to the optic chiasma, the aneurysm may protrude posteriorly and compress the optic chiasma from above.
  • This can result in bitemporal hemianopia, or loss of vision in the left/temporal halves of both visual fields, as the nasal fibers of each retina cross through the chiasma at this level and may be affected.
  • Therefore, it is likely that the aneurysm is causing damage to the optic chiasma and resulting in the patient's vision loss.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Anterior choroidal artery: This artery arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies parts of the hippocampus, lateral geniculate body, posterior limb of the internal capsule, and the choroid plexus of the lateral and third ventricles.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: It doesn't have a direct relationship with the optic chiasma, so an aneurysm here is less likely to cause vision disturbances related to chiasmal compression.

 

Option C. Middle cerebral artery (MCA): It is one of the three major paired arteries that supply the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies a significant portion of the lateral convexity of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The MCA is located laterally and doesn't directly overlie the optic chiasma. Thus, an aneurysm of the MCA typically would not impinge upon the optic chiasma.

 

Option D. Anterior cerebral artery (ACA): It is one of the major paired arteries that supplies the brain's cerebrum. It arises from the internal carotid artery and supplies the medial and superior parts of the cerebral hemisphere.

 

  • Relation to Optic Chiasma: The ACA runs superiorly to the optic chiasma, similar to the anterior communicating artery. However, the anterior communicating artery, given its position and course, is more commonly associated with aneurysms that affect the optic chiasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior communicating artery connects the two anterior cerebral arteries and is a part of the Circle of Willis, a circulatory anastomosis that supplies the brain.

 

Relation to Optic Chiasma: The anterior communicating artery runs superiorly to the optic chiasma. An aneurysm of this artery can impinge upon or compress the optic chiasma leading to visual disturbances, especially a particular kind of vision loss called bitemporal hemianopsia.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors are responsible for tactile discrimination? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meissner's corpuscle

 

Meissner's Corpuscles are responsible for discriminative touch.

 

 

 

Meissner’s corpuscle

 

Touch receptor with great sensitivity

An elongated encapsulated nerve ending of a large (type AB. myelinated sensory nerve fiber. Inside the capsulation are many branching terminal nerve filaments.

 

Present in the non-hairy parts of the skin and are particularly abundant in the fingertips, lips, and other areas of the skin where one’s ability to discern spatial locations of touch sensations is highly developed.

 

These are responsible for-Two Point discrimination, Fine touch and Slow vibration

 

If the question asks - Best for 2 point discrimination/ best for Braille reading/ static 2 point discrimination - the answer is Merkel


If the question asks - Most common/ most abundant/ maximum on glabrous skin/ primary / dynamic 2 point discrimination - the answer is Meissners
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merkel Disc: Allows one to determine continuous touch of objects against the skin.

 

Option B. Ruffini End Organ: Responsible for temperature sensation.

 

Option C. Pacinian Corpuscle: Responsible for pressure and crude touch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meissner's corpuscles are specialized for discriminative touch, enabling precise location and detection of fine tactile stimuli. They are most abundant in areas where tactile acuity is high, such as the fingertips and lips

questions.text: A child presented with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. X ray is shown. Which of the following should be corrected before surgery? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

The X-ray image shows a characteristic "single bubble" sign, which is indicative of pyloric stenosis or pyloric atresia. In this condition, there is obstruction at the pylorus, leading to recurrent non-bilious vomiting. The continuous vomiting results in significant electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypokalemia with hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

 

Hypokalemia is the most critical electrolyte disturbance that needs to be corrected before surgery in these patients. This is because:

 

  1. It's a direct result of the continuous vomiting and loss of potassium-rich gastric contents.
  2. Low potassium levels can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, which pose a significant risk during surgery.
  3. Correcting hypokalemia is essential for maintaining proper muscle function, including that of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Incorrect. Pyloric stenosis typically causes hypokalemia, not hyperkalemia.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: Incorrect. While hyponatremia can occur, hypokalemia is the more urgent concern in this scenario.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: Incorrect. Hypernatremia is not typically associated with pyloric stenosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pyloric stenosis, characterized by recurrent non-bilious vomiting and a "single bubble" sign on X-ray, hypokalemia is the most critical electrolyte imbalance that must be corrected before surgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient with dyspnea, respiratory distress due to pan-acinar emphysema, and liver dysfunction is due to a likely defect in which of the following? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency of the alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein, which protects the lungs from neutrophil elastase.

 

This deficiency leads to the development of pan-acinar emphysema, especially in the lower lobes of the lungs, and liver dysfunction, such as cirrhosis, due to the accumulation of abnormal alpha 1 anti-trypsin in hepatocytes.

 

The combination of pulmonary and hepatic manifestations, particularly pan-acinar emphysema, is a hallmark of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ATP7A gene: Mutations in this gene are associated with Menkes disease, a disorder of copper metabolism, leading to systemic copper deficiency. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction seen in alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency.

 

Option B. ATP7B gene: This gene is associated with Wilson's disease, which affects copper metabolism, leading to liver disease and neurological symptoms but not emphysema.

 

Option D. Surfactant defect: Surfactant deficiency typically occurs in preterm infants, leading to respiratory distress syndrome due to immature lung development. It does not cause emphysema or liver dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alpha 1 anti-trypsin deficiency is associated with pan-acinar emphysema and liver dysfunction due to a deficiency of the protective alpha 1 anti-trypsin protein.

questions.text: Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are clinical manifestations associated with a deficiency in Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin). Riboflavin is essential for various cellular processes, including energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids. Deficiency in riboflavin leads to various symptoms, most notably affecting the mucous membranes, which include angular cheilitis (cracking at the corners of the mouth), stomatitis (inflammation of the mouth and lips), and glossitis (inflammation of the tongue).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Thiamine deficiency is not typically associated with angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis. Instead, it leads to conditions such as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi, which affect the nervous and cardiovascular systems.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the three D's: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While oral symptoms can occur in severe cases, they usually do not present as angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with dermatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and certain types of anemia. It is not typically linked with angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are associated with Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) deficiency.

choices.text: Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

questions.text: Identify the condition and the instrument:(NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Periarticular fracture of knee, spanning fixator

 

RULE OF IMMOBILISATION

 

  • Immobilise one joint above and 1 joint below the main target
  • Femur fracture: Fixation at hip joint and knee joint
  • Tibia fracture: Fixation at knee joint and ankle joint
  • Periarticular Knee fracture: Fixation at hip joint and ankle joint
  • Peri- and intra-articular fractures about the knee are frequently managed with joint-spanning external fixation before definitive treatment.
  • With a systematic approach, a near-anatomic reduction with respect to length, alignment, and rotation can be obtained.

 

KNEE SPANNING EXTERNAL FIXATOR

 

  • A joint-bridging external fixator is fixed to the femur and the tibia while the fracture zone is left virtually untouched (it is bridged).
  • Provisional reduction is achieved with distraction.
  • When external fixation is used to bridge the knee joint, it is always only for temporary fixation. Prolonged immobilization will lead to difficulties with knee mobility.
  • It is rapidly applied without need for intraoperative x-rays and can be adjusted later.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Tibia fracture, Ilizarov fixator. The most stable external fixation for distal tibial fractures is usually composed by:

 

  • One fully circular ring with tensioned wires attached to the distal tibial articular segment
  • Two proximal fully circular rings to provide stable anchorage for the distal ring
  • An extension for the foot and ankle, and particularly for intraarticular fractures
  • 3-4 connecting rods between each ring

 

The proximal rings can be anchored with Schanz screws or tensioned wires. Wires are usually used in cancellous bone. Wires attached to a circular ring are typically tensioned at 100 to 130 kg-force.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

A spanning external fixator is used for stabilization of open and closed fractures, mainly intraarticular fractures of the lower extremity, around the knee and ankle joints.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the emergency department with head trauma due to a road traffic accident. In the hospital, the patient developed seizures. An emergency CT scan revealed widespread cerebral edema. Which of the following is the diuretic of choice for cerebral edema in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mannitol

 

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic and is the drug of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in cases of traumatic brain injury, like the one described. Mannitol works by creating an osmotic gradient that draws fluid out of the brain parenchyma and into the intravascular space, thereby reducing intracranial pressure and alleviating cerebral edema. This makes it the first-line treatment in emergency situations involving cerebral edema.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic that works by antagonizing aldosterone in the distal nephron. It is not effective in managing cerebral edema and is primarily used in conditions like heart failure and certain cases of hyperaldosteronism.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that is effective in treating peripheral and pulmonary edema by inhibiting the reabsorption of sodium and chloride in the loop of Henle. While it is a potent diuretic, it is not the first choice for cerebral edema because it does not effectively lower intracranial pressure as mannitol does.

 

Option D. Hydrochlorothiazide: Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used mainly for hypertension and mild fluid retention. It is not used in the treatment of cerebral edema and would not be effective in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mannitol is the diuretic of choice for treating cerebral edema, particularly in emergency settings following traumatic brain injury, due to its ability to reduce intracranial pressure by drawing fluid out of the brain tissue.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic with a concern about a hypopigmented patch on her forearm. She has noticed reduced sensation over the patch. During the physical examination, you also notice thickening of some peripheral nerves. Which of the following combinations of criteria would be appropriate for diagnosing Leprosy in suspected cases? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Hypopigmented skin lesions with sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening
  3. Family history of leprosy
  4. Slit skin smears
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

To diagnose Leprosy, at least one of the following cardinal signs must be present:

 

1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit: This is a primary indicator of Leprosy. The presence of sensory deficits in these lesions points to the nerve involvement characteristic of the disease.

 

2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis: Thickening of peripheral nerves, combined with sensory loss and muscle weakening or paralysis, is another key indicator of Leprosy. These clinical signs suggest the spread of the infection to peripheral nerves.

 

4. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears): This involves laboratory confirmation through slit skin smears showing the presence of Mycobacterium leprae. It is a definitive diagnostic method for Leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. family history of leprosy is not considered one of the cardinal signs necessary for diagnosis. It is more relevant in understanding the epidemiological context rather than serving as a primary diagnostic criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At least one of the following cardinal signs must be present to diagnose Leprosy

 

  1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis
  3. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears)

choices.text: Chordee correction, meatal advancement, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty
Meatal advancement, chordee correction, glanuloplasty, urethral mobilization

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence for correction of hypospadias surgery? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chordee correction, urethral mobilization, glanuloplasty

 

  • Proximal hypospadias with chordee needs surgical correction and may involve a two-stage repair. The first stage corrects the penile curvature and the second stage repairs the urethra. Circumcision should be avoided as preputial skin may be required for future repairs or revisions. Surgery for hypospadias is best performed by experts in hypospadias surgery and is typically undertaken before the age of 18 months
  • Chordee correction involves straightening the penis, which may have a downward curvature.
  • Urethral mobilization involves the dissection of the urethra from the corpora cavernosa and mobilizing it to a normal anatomical position.
  • Glanuloplasty involves the reconstruction of the glans penis to provide a cosmetically pleasing appearance and improve function.
  • Meatal advancement involves the creation of a normal urethral meatus at the tip of the penis.

questions.text: Which factor is associated with the Leiden mutation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) V

 

Leiden mutation is a single nucleotide mutation that occurs in factor V.

 

Factor V Leiden (FVL) is a point mutation of factor V resulting in an elimination of the cleavage site in factor V and factor Va. Activated protein C, a natural anticoagulant cannot bind and inactivate factor V as there is a mutation in the binding site on factor V for activated protein C. Therefore, as factor V is not inactivated it continues to be active and increases thrombosis risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. VIII: Factor VIII is involved in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade and is affected in conditions like hemophilia A. 

 

Option C. I: Factor I, also known as fibrinogen, is a protein involved in the final step of the clotting process, forming fibrin clots.

 

Option D. X: Factor X, part of both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, is crucial for the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Leiden mutation specifically affects factor V, rendering it resistant to inactivation by activated protein C, unlike factors VIII, I, or X.

questions.text: The membrane covering an omphalocele is primarily formed by which of the following embryonic structures? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amnion

 

An omphalocele is a congenital defect in which the intestines or other abdominal organs protrude outside of the body through the umbilical ring but are covered by a protective membrane. This membrane consists of multiple layers:

 

  • Inner Layer: The inner layer of the covering is the peritoneum, which lines the abdominal cavity.
  • Middle Layer: Wharton’s jelly, a gelatinous substance, is located between the peritoneum and the outer covering.
  • Outer Layer: The outermost layer of the covering is derived from the amnion, which is part of the fetal membrane surrounding the developing fetus.

 

Thus, the amnion forms the outermost layer covering the omphalocele, providing protection to the protruding organs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endoderm: The endoderm is the innermost germ layer that gives rise to internal structures like the lining of the gastrointestinal tract, not the covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option B. Mesoderm: The mesoderm forms muscles, bones, and connective tissues but does not specifically contribute to the external covering of an omphalocele.

 

Option C. Chorion: The chorion is another fetal membrane that participates in placental formation but does not directly form the covering of the omphalocele.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The outer covering of an omphalocele is derived from the amnion, with the peritoneum lining the inner surface and Wharton’s jelly situated between the peritoenum and outer covering.

questions.text:
A persistent alcoholic patient presents with convulsions and impaired sensorium. He has been drinking for ten years and consumes 24 units every day. His most recent drink was two days ago. He is discovered to have auditory hallucinations as well as secondary delusions. What method will you employ to manage this patient?

 

  1. Diazepam
  2. Thiamine
  3. Naltrexone
  4. Flupenthixol depot injection
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2

 

The patient is presenting with symptoms of alcohol withdrawal, specifically delirium tremens, characterized by tremors, altered sensorium, hallucinations, seizures, and agitation.

 

1. Diazepam: Benzodiazepines, like diazepam, are the first line of treatment for alcohol withdrawal symptoms and can help reduce the severity of symptoms, prevent seizures, and can be titrated based on the severity of withdrawal.

 

2. Thiamine: Chronic alcoholics are at risk for thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, leading to Wernicke's encephalopathy. It is important to administer thiamine before or with the first dose of glucose-containing fluids or foods to prevent precipitating or exacerbating Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Naltrexone: This is an opioid antagonist that is used to decrease alcohol cravings. It is not directly useful in treating acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

4. Flupenthixol depot injection: This is an antipsychotic medication. It is not the primary treatment for alcohol withdrawal.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. Risk factors include surgery, infections or other medical conditions. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention. Treatment includes intravenous lorazepam or diazepam with thiamine supplementation to prevent Wernicke encephalopathy.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 472-473.

choices.text: Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology
IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control
DC Cardioversion is required in all cases
Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis

questions.text: A 38-year-old man collapsed and was brought to the emergency. ECG was taken and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) was made. Which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control

 

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is characterized by an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves on ECG, which confirms the diagnosis. Each of the provided options needs to be evaluated for accuracy.

 

IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control. This is the correct statement. IV Digoxin is used for rate control in AF, particularly in patients with heart failure.

 

If the patient is stable and not in acute heart failure, beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like verapamil or diltiazem are preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology: This statement is incorrect. Atrial fibrillation can occur in morphologically normal hearts. Studies indicate that 15-35% of AF cases can be seen in individuals with structurally normal hearts, although it is more common in those with conditions such as heart failure or left atrial enlargement.

 

Option C. DC Cardioversion is required in all cases: This statement is incorrect. DC cardioversion is reserved for unstable patients or for rhythm control in selected chronic cases. It is not required for all AF cases.

 

Option D. Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis: This statement is incorrect. While a pulse deficit (difference between heart rate and pulse rate) can suggest AF, it is not a reliable diagnostic criterion as it can be observed in other conditions such as frequent ventricular premature contractions, cardiac tamponade, and severe heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IV Digoxin can be effectively used for ventricular rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in those with heart failure.

choices.text: Both (a) and (b)

questions.text: In which trimester does acute fatty liver manifest most commonly during pregnancy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Third trimester

 

Explanation:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP) is a life-threatening medical disorder that primarily affects the liver during pregnancy. It most commonly manifests in the late second and third trimesters. AFLP is characterized by the accumulation of microvesicular fat within hepatocytes, leading to liver dysfunction. The diagnosis of AFLP is made using the Swansea criteria, which require six or more of the following clinical features for diagnosis:

 

  • Vomiting
  • Abdominal pain
  • Polydipsia, polyuria
  • Encephalopathy
  • Coagulopathy (raised PT, aPTT)
  • Increased bilirubin
  • Increased uric acid levels
  • Increased creatinine
  • Leukocytosis
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Raised liver enzymes
  • Raised serum ammonia levels
  • Ascites or bright liver on ultrasound
  • Microvascular steatosis on liver biopsy

 

Risk Factors:

 

  • Maternal obesity
  • Male fetus
  • Primigravida
  • Multiple pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First trimester: AFLP is very rare in the first trimester, as it typically manifests later in pregnancy.

 

Option B. Second trimester: While AFLP can begin in the late second trimester, it is more commonly seen in the third trimester.

 

Option D. Both (a) and (b): AFLP does not commonly manifest in the first trimester and is primarily a condition of the late second and third trimesters.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy most commonly manifests in the third trimester and is diagnosed using the Swansea criteria, requiring six or more specific clinical features.

 

Ref: Page no 2684, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: 1- right kidney, 2- pancreas, 3- left kidney

questions.text: Identify the structures marked. (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) 1- liver 2-spleen 3-pancreas

 

Explanation:

 

 

Other Option:

 

Option D: 1- liver, 2- spleen, 3- pancreas: Correct based on organ anatomy and typical CT appearance.

 

Educational Objective :

 

Accurate identification of abdominal organs on imaging studies like CT scans is essential for diagnosing diseases, planning surgeries, and tracking treatment progress.

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Nocardia
  2. Mycobacterium leprae
  3. Actinomyces
  4. Cryptosporidium parvum
  5. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 4, 5

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Cystoisospora belli (Options 1, 2, 4, and 5) are acid-fast staining organisms.

 

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolorization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state. The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Nelson are:

 

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolorized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin color, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

 

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Other Option

 

3. Actinomyces: Actinomyces is not an acid-fast organism. They are gram-positive bacteria that are known for forming filamentous structures similar to fungi but do not retain the acid-fast stain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, Cryptosporidium parvum, and Isospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

1.Hypokalemia

2.Hypochloremia

3.Metabolic alkalosis

4.Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea can lead to multiple metabolic abnormalities: Hypokalemia, Hypochloremia, metabolic alkalosis with hyponatremia.

 

1. Hypokalemia: Loss of potassium through vomiting and diarrhea.

 

2. Hypochloremia: Loss of chloride.

 

3. Metabolic alkalosis: Loss of gastric acids.

 

These changes are due to the loss of electrolytes and fluids.

 

Other Option:

 

4. Respiratory alkalosis involves hyperventilation and a decrease in carbon dioxide, which is unrelated to the described condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Severe vomiting and diarrhea typically cause hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and metabolic alkalosis.

choices.text: Metastatic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level
Metastatic calcification with increased serum calcium levels
Dystrophic calcification with increased serum calcium level

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presented with cervical lymphadenopathy. Biopsy shows granulomatous inflammation with calcification. Which of the following is correct? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dystrophic calcification with normal serum calcium level

 

In this case, the presence of granulomatous inflammation with calcification in the cervical lymph nodes is indicative of dystrophic calcification. Dystrophic calcification occurs in damaged or degenerating tissues, often associated with chronic inflammation or necrosis, while the serum calcium levels remain normal. This type of calcification is a localized process and doesn't require systemic calcium metabolism disturbances.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastatic calcification with normal serum calcium level: Incorrect. Metastatic calcification occurs in normal tissues due to hypercalcemia, which is not present in this case.

 

Option C. Metastatic calcification with increased serum calcium levels: Incorrect. While metastatic calcification does involve increased serum calcium levels, the scenario described (granulomatous inflammation in lymph nodes) is more consistent with dystrophic calcification.

 

Option D. Dystrophic calcification with increased serum calcium level: Incorrect. Dystrophic calcification occurs with normal serum calcium levels. Increased serum calcium is not a feature of dystrophic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granulomatous inflammation with calcification in tissues, particularly in the context of chronic inflammation or tissue damage, is characteristic of dystrophic calcification, which occurs in the presence of normal serum calcium levels.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and hemoglobin is 6 g/dL. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia, and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario? (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Chest X-ray
  2. Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
  3. Absolute neutrophil count
  4. Leucocyte antibodies
  5. Platelets
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 2

 

The patient presents with signs and symptoms indicative of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), which includes elevated mean arterial pressure, hypoxemia, and respiratory distress following a blood transfusion. TACO occurs due to fluid overload from the transfusion, leading to pulmonary edema and increased cardiac filling pressures.

 

1. Chest X-ray: This imaging is crucial as it can reveal bilateral infiltrates indicative of pulmonary edema, a hallmark of TACO. It helps to differentiate between TACO and other causes of respiratory distress post-transfusion.

 

2. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) Level: BNP is a cardiac biomarker that is elevated in conditions of increased cardiac pressure and volume overload, such as TACO. Elevated BNP levels would support the diagnosis of TACO, whereas BNP levels would not be elevated in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), another potential complication post-transfusion that presents with respiratory distress but usually with hypotension.

 

Other Options:

 

3. Absolute neutrophil count and 5. platelets are not specific for diagnosing TACO or TRALI. These parameters do not provide information on fluid overload or cardiac stress.

 

4. Leucocyte antibodies are not directly relevant to the diagnosis of TACO. Leucocyte antibodies might be involved in TRALI, but not TACO.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with suspected transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO), the best investigations are a chest X-ray to detect pulmonary edema and BNP levels to assess cardiac stress and fluid overload

questions.text: An old man has recurrent fainting episodes. His ECG shows P-waves at 75/min, QRS complexes are at 35 bpm. The clinical diagnosis is: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Stokes-Adams Syndrome

 

The patient has recurrent fainting episodes, and his ECG shows a discrepancy between the rate of P-waves (75/min) and QRS complexes (35 bpm), indicating an AV block.

 

In this case, the P-waves are getting blocked at the AV node, leading to fewer QRS complexes.

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome refers to recurrent fainting/ syncopal episodes caused by sudden fluctuations in cardiac output, paroxysmal Bradycardia often due to AV blocks such as complete heart block or second-degree AV block (Mobitz type II).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Electrical alternans: This is seen in cardiac tamponade and is characterized by beat-to-beat variations in QRS amplitude or axis. The patient would present with signs of tamponade such as hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distension, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Atrial tachycardia: This would present with a ventricular response rate of more than 100 bpm and would typically involve abnormal P-wave morphology. The patient in this case has bradycardia (QRS at 35 bpm), excluding atrial tachycardia.

 

Option C. First degree AV block: This is characterized by a prolonged PR interval with a 1:1 P to QRS ratio. The discrepancy between P-wave and QRS complex rates in this case excludes first degree AV block.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stokes-Adams Syndrome involves recurrent fainting episodes due to sudden changes in cardiac output, typically from AV block-related bradycardia. Recognizing the discrepancy between atrial and ventricular rates is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: Imagine you are a clinician administering vaccines to a group of travelers going to a region with high Hepatitis B prevalence. One of the travelers, who has a background in biology, curiously asks which specific part of the Hepatitis B virus is actually present in the vaccine to induce an immune response. Out of the given options, which antigen is included in the Hepatitis B subunit vaccine? [INICET NOV 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) HbsAg

 

  • Hepatitis B is endemic throughout the world
  • Hepatitis B subunit vaccines consist of HBsAg (Hepatitis B virus surface antigen).
  • These vaccines are created using large molecules obtained from the immunogenic parts of pathogens through recombinant DNA technology.
  • They contrast with fully inactivated whole-cell vaccines as they exclusively contain the antigenic elements of the pathogen.
  • These elements are essential for prompting a defensive immune reaction.

 

Vaccines for Hepatitis B:

 

  • Plasma derived vaccine:
    • Is formalin inactivated sub-unit vaccine
    • Is based on HBsAg
    • Derived from carriers of Hepatitis B
    • Hepatitis B vaccine, dose schedule in adult (months) 0, 1, 6 months
  • rDNA yeast derived vaccine: Recombinant DNA vaccine (genetically engineered)

 

Hepatitis B Immunoglobulin: 

 

  • Required for immediate protection:
    • Surgeons, nurse, laboratory workers
    • Newborn infants of carrier mothers
    • Sexual contacts of acute Hepatitis B patients
    • Ideally administered within 6 hours (not later than 48 hours)

  • Dose: 0.05–0.07 mL/kg, 2 doses 30 days apart

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Hepatitis B subunit vaccine contains HBsAg, which is essential for inducing an immune response against the virus.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the point from A to C in the given flowchart depicting the natural history of a disease? [NEET PG 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lead time

 

Lead time is defined as the interval between the point a condition is detected through screening and the Time it would normally have been detected due to appearance and reporting of signs and symptoms.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Screening time:  This term refers to the period during which screening tests are conducted to detect disease in asymptomatic individuals.

 

Option C. Lag time:  This term is generally used to describe a delay between the onset of an event and its detection or measurement. In the context of disease, lag time could refer to the delay between symptom onset and diagnosis.

 

Option D. Generation time:  This term is typically used in epidemiology to describe the time interval between the infection of a host and the subsequent transmission of the disease to another host. It does not relate to the timeline of diagnosis within an individual patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lead time is the interval between the detection of a disease through screening and its usual time of diagnosis due to symptom presentation.

 

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening (leading the time of diagnosis)

 

Early detection of disease due to screening (B rather than C) will ensure earlier institution of treatment, thus better prognosis.

questions.text: An adult female came with curdy white vaginal discharge. Microscopic examination showed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae. What can be the causative organism? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Candida albicans

 

The key points indicate Candida albicans as the causative organism are:

 

  1. The patient presented with curdy white vaginal discharge, which is a common symptom of candidiasis (yeast infection).
  2. Microscopic examination revealed gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae, which are characteristic of Candida albicans.
  3. Pseudohyphae are elongated structures with constrictions at the septal junctions, distinguishing them from true hyphae found in molds.
  4. Among the options provided, Candida albicans is the only fungus that forms pseudohyphae.

 

Candida albicans is a yeast that can cause various fungal infections, including vaginal candidiasis (commonly known as a "yeast infection"). The formation of pseudohyphae, along with budding yeast cells, is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans observed under the microscope.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bacterial vaginosis: This condition is caused by an overgrowth of various bacteria, not a fungus like Candida albicans.

 

Option C. Trichomoniasis: This is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis, not a fungus.

 

Option D.  Gonorrhoea: Caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae, presents with purulent discharge but does not produce yeast or pseudohyphae. Diagnosis is typically confirmed with gram stain and culture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Candida albicans is a fungus that can cause vaginal candidiasis (yeast infection), characterized by a curdy white vaginal discharge. The presence of gram-positive budding yeast and pseudohyphae on microscopic examination is a distinctive feature of Candida albicans infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is observed with Philadelphia chromosome:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Reciprocal translocation

 

Explanation:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome, characteristic of Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), is the result of a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, denoted as t(9;22) (q34;q11).

 

This translocation leads to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which encodes a constitutively active tyrosine kinase that drives the uncontrolled proliferation of myeloid cells in CML.

 

The presence of the BCR-ABL fusion gene can be detected using Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization (FISH), a highly specific and sensitive technique for identifying chromosomal abnormalities. The identification of this fusion gene is crucial for the diagnosis of CML and for guiding targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors such as imatinib.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Inversion involves a reversal of a chromosomal segment within a single chromosome and is not the mechanism underlying the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Option C. Deletion refers to the loss of a portion of a chromosome and is not the primary chromosomal abnormality in CML.

 

Option D. Insertion involves the integration of a segment of one chromosome into another chromosome and is not the characteristic finding in the Philadelphia chromosome.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Philadelphia chromosome in CML is the result of a reciprocal translocation between chromosomes 9 and 22, leading to the formation of the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which can be detected using FISH and is the target of tyrosine kinase inhibitor therapy.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

 

Out of the options given above, amoxicillin is the only drug which is an antibiotic. It is an amino penicillin. Allergic reactions in the form of skin rashes to Penicillin group of antibiotics are very common, out of which it is the highest with aminopenicillins.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used in the treatment of asthma to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically associated with causing maculopapular rashes. In fact, they are often used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

 

Options B. Salbutamol: Also known as albuterol, this is a bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in conditions like asthma. Salbutamol is not commonly associated with skin rashes like a maculopapular rash.

 

Options C. Fexofenadine: This is an antihistamine used for allergic reactions. It is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash and is more commonly used to treat such rashes when they are due to allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

questions.text: 14-year-old boy with recurrent profuse epistaxis and reddish mass in the nasal cavity: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) JNA (Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma)

 

A 14-year-old boy presenting with recurrent, profuse epistaxis (nosebleeds) and a reddish mass in the nasal cavity is highly suggestive of Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA). JNA is a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that predominantly affects adolescent males. The hallmark symptoms include recurrent severe nosebleeds and nasal obstruction due to the tumor mass.

 

Key characteristics of JNA:

 

  • Occurs in adolescent males
  • Presents with recurrent, profuse epistaxis
  • Appears as a reddish mass in the nasal cavity

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NPC (Nasopharyngeal carcinoma): Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is typically seen in older adults and is associated with risk factors like consumption of nitrosamine-rich foods (e.g., salted fish). It often presents with unilateral hearing loss due to Eustachian tube blockage, leading to serous otitis media. It is not common in adolescents and does not typically present with recurrent epistaxis.

 

Option C. Polyp: Nasal polyps are benign growths in the nasal cavity that usually do not bleed. They can cause nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea but are not typically associated with recurrent, profuse epistaxis.

 

Option D. Inverted papilloma: Inverted papillomas are benign tumors that usually occur in older adults. They are associated with a risk of malignancy and often present with unilateral nasal obstruction and occasional bleeding but not the recurrent, profuse epistaxis seen in JNA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) should be suspected in adolescent males who present with recurrent, profuse epistaxis and a reddish mass in the nasal cavity. This condition is characteristic of this age and gender group and requires specific clinical suspicion for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: A laborer's second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor

 

The clinical presentation of a swollen belly and dull face in a child fed mostly rice water, along with findings of low serum protein and low albumin, is suggestive of Kwashiorkor.

 

Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition characterized by:

 

  • Edema: Resulting from hypoalbuminemia, which leads to fluid retention and swelling, especially in the abdomen.
  • Apathy and irritability: The child often appears listless and irritable.
  • Poor diet history: Often associated with diets low in protein, such as those predominantly consisting of carbohydrates like rice water.
  • Other symptoms: Growth retardation, muscle wasting, and skin and hair changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe acute malnutrition but is characterized by severe wasting and absence of edema. Children with marasmus appear extremely thin with prominent ribs and have a "skin and bones" appearance.

 

Option C. Indian childhood cirrhosis: This is a chronic liver disease in children characterized by liver fibrosis and cirrhosis, but it does not typically present with the acute signs of protein malnutrition like Kwashiorkor.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: This is an acute febrile illness of unknown etiology that primarily affects children under 5 years of age and involves inflammation of blood vessels (vasculitis). It does not present with symptoms of malnutrition such as a swollen belly due to low protein intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kwashiorkor is characterized by edema, apathy, and growth retardation due to a diet deficient in protein, often with a swollen belly and low serum protein levels.

questions.text: RNAi acts through? (INICET May 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Knock down

 

Explanation:

 

Gene knock down is when function of the gene present is suppressed by inhibiting or degrading the target mRNA so that it cannot form its protein. This is also known as post transcriptional gene silencing or RNA interference (RNAi). This is mediated by micro RNA (miRNA) or small interfering RNA (siRNA) which are small 20-27 nucleotides long non-coding RNAs. miRNA based RNAi involves the uses of three enzymes DROSHA, PASHA and DICER.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Knock out: This involves removing or taking a gene out, resulting in a complete loss of gene function.

 

Option C. Knock in: This involves inserting a gene into a specific location within the genome.

 

Option D. Knock up: This term is not used in the context of gene manipulation.

 

Educational Objective:


RNA interference (RNAi) acts through gene knock down by suppressing the function of a gene via degradation or inhibition of its target mRNA, preventing protein formation.

 

Ref- Harper 31st e/p 346-348

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not involved in Th1 response? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IL- 4

 

The cytokine not involved in TH1 response is IL-4.

 

T-cell response in this early stage is dominated by TH1 cells that produce IFN-γ, which stimulates macrophages to secrete high levels of the cytokines TNF, IL-1, and IL-6 that cause fever.

 

IL-12 is secreted by macrophages and promotes the proliferation of TH1 cells.

 

The 1 cells secrete IL-2 which activates natural killer cells (NK cells) and cytotoxic T cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma): IFN-γ (Interferon-gamma) is a key cytokine produced by Th1 cells. It activates macrophages and enhances their ability to destroy ingested microbes, and it also promotes the production of IgG antibodies that are essential for opsonization and phagocytosis of pathogens.

 

Option B. IL-2 (Interleukin-2): IL-2 (Interleukin-2) is produced by Th1 cells and plays a critical role in the activation and proliferation of T cells, including natural killer (NK) cells and cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs), which are crucial for the immune response against intracellular pathogens.

 

Option C. IL-12 (Interleukin-12): IL-12 (Interleukin-12) is produced by antigen-presenting cells (like dendritic cells and macrophages) and is essential for the differentiation of naive T cells into Th1 cells. It also stimulates the production of IFN-γ by these Th1 cells.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the classification: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mallampati score

 

Explanation:

 

The image shown is the Mallampati classification. It classifies the ease of visualization of the oral structures (uvula, soft palate, and tonsillar pillars) when a patient opens their mouth and protrudes their tongue. This classification helps predict the difficulty of endotracheal intubation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aldrete score: This scoring system is used to assess the recovery of a patient post-surgery, focusing on activity, respiration, circulation, consciousness, and oxygen saturation.

 

Option C. Ramsay score: The Ramsay Score is a scale for assessing the level of sedation in patients, particularly in a critical care setting.

 

Option D. Z score: The Z score is a statistical measurement that describes a value's relationship to the mean of a group of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mallampati classification is utilized to assess the potential difficulty of endotracheal intubation by examining the visibility of anatomical structures in the oral cavity.

questions.text: A family consumes only polished rice. Which of the following combination of vitamin deficiency and enzymatic defect will be present in this family? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine – Transketolase

 

This is the correct combination. Consuming polished rice can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Transketolase is an enzyme involved in thiamine-dependent reactions, and its activity can be affected by thiamine deficiency, leading to various health issues, including beriberi, which is associated with thiamine deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin - Glutathione Reductase: This combination is not relevant to the consumption of polished rice. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and glutathione reductase is not directly related to this deficiency.

 

Option C. Thiamine - Transaminase: While thiamine deficiency can affect various enzymes, transaminase is not specifically associated with thiamine deficiency related to polished rice consumption.

 

Option D. Riboflavin - Transketolase: This combination is not relevant to polished rice consumption. Riboflavin deficiency is not typically associated with polished rice consumption, and transketolase is not directly related to riboflavin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The consumption of polished rice leads to thiamine deficiency which leads to defective transketolase activity.

 

Polished rice undergoes milling, which removes the outer bran layer rich in B vitamins and other nutrients

choices.text: If the hands are visibly soiled
While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care

questions.text: A healthcare worker is performing patient care in a hospital setting. Which of the following is not a correct situation for using hand rub according to standard hand hygiene protocol? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) If the hands are visibly soiled

 

Hand rub, typically alcohol-based hand sanitizer, is not effective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with dirt, blood, or other body fluids. In such cases, healthcare workers should wash their hands with soap and water to physically remove the visible contaminants before using hand rub. This is a crucial step to ensure proper hand hygiene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. While moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub when transitioning from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. This helps prevent the spread of pathogens and maintain aseptic conditions. It's an essential practice in infection control

 

Option C. Before donning on gloves: Correct. Hand hygiene, including the use of hand rub, is recommended before putting on gloves. This step ensures that any potential contaminants on the hands are removed before glove use, reducing the risk of contamination during procedures .

 

Option D. During direct patient contact: Correct. Healthcare workers should use hand rub before and after direct patient contact to reduce the risk of transmitting pathogens to or from the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand hygiene is essential for infection prevention in healthcare settings. Alcohol-based hand rubs are preferred in most cases, but soap and water should be used for visibly soiled hands and in cases of outbreaks of certain pathogens like Clostridium difficile. Hand hygiene should be performed before and after every direct patient contact, before donning gloves, and after removing gloves. Additionally, hand hygiene should be performed while moving from a contaminated site to a clean site during patient care. It is important to note that using hand rub is not appropriate if the hands are visibly soiled, as the rub cannot effectively remove dirt and debris from the hands. In such cases, soap and water handwashing is recommended.

questions.text:
Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. DEXA
  2. Bone scan
  3. Quantitative CT
  4. Chemical analysis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) II, IV are correct

 

OSTEOPOROSIS (V > H > C)

 

  • Osteoporosis is reduction in bone mass (density) i.e., there is quantitative decrease of units of bone formation but each unit has qualitatively normal configuration.
  • Bone mineral density is measured by DEXA scan (65 years onwards)
  • Normal Ca2+, PO‑4, ALP
  • Hemiplegic – Humerus maximum loss of bone mineral density

 

 

  • Radiological Investigation: 
    • Quantitative CT is a newer imaging technique that can be used to detect osteoporosis
    • Radiological features are loss of vertical height of vertebrae (collapse) and codfish appearance (concave superior and inferior surfaces) of vertebrae.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Estrogen
    • Bisphosphonates – Increases hip fracture.
    • Calcitonin
    • Low dose PTH – Stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A bone scan helps to examine any irregularities in the bone. Sometimes, these bone irregularities may indicate either infection or cancer disease. In addition, it can also help to detect arthritis and bone fractures.

  • Chemical analysis test will not show any diagnostic change because the serum calcium, phosphate, and alkaline phosphatase levels remains normal in osteoporosis. The problem with osteoporosis is of bone quality and not its chemical makeup.

     

Educational Objective:

 

  • DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

questions.text: A pregnant woman comes to the clinic. She already has twins by normal delivery. Which of the following is the correct representation of her obstetric score? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) G2P1

 

In obstetric history, gravida (G) refers to the number of pregnancies a woman has had, including the current pregnancy, regardless of the outcome or duration. Parity (P) refers to the number of pregnancies that have reached the period of viability (28 weeks in India). Each pregnancy is counted once, regardless of the number of fetuses (e.g., twins count as one pregnancy).

 

  • Gravida (G): Number of pregnancies, including the current one.
  • Parity (P): Number of pregnancies that have reached viability (28 weeks or more), not including the current pregnancy.

 

In this case:

 

  • The woman has had one previous pregnancy that resulted in the birth of twins.
  • She is currently pregnant with her second pregnancy.

 

Therefore, her obstetric score is:

 

  • G2 (Gravida 2): This is her second pregnancy.
  • P1 (Para 1): She has had one previous pregnancy that reached viability and resulted in the birth of twins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. G3P2: This would imply she has had three pregnancies and two that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Option B. G3P1: This would imply she is in her third pregnancy, which is incorrect.

 

Option D. G2P2: This would imply she has had two previous pregnancies that reached viability, which is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In obstetric scoring, twin pregnancies count as a single gravida, and the obstetric score for a woman with twins by normal delivery and currently pregnant should be G2P1.

questions.text: All are features of Conn's syndrome except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metabolic acidosis

 

Explanation:

 

Conn's syndrome, also known as primary hyperaldosteronism, is characterized by an excess production of aldosterone, usually due to an adrenal adenoma.

 

The typical features of Conn's syndrome include:

 

  • Hypertension: Due to increased sodium and water retention.
  • Hypokalemia: Caused by increased potassium excretion.
  • Metabolic alkalosis: Due to increased hydrogen ion excretion and bicarbonate retention.

 

Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of Conn's syndrome. It is more commonly associated with conditions where there is a deficiency of aldosterone, such as adrenal insufficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metabolic alkalosis: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to aldosterone's effect on renal tubular excretion of hydrogen ions.

 

Option C. Hypertension: Correctly associated with Conn's syndrome due to sodium and water retention.

 

Option D. Muscle cramps: Can be associated with hypokalemia seen in Conn's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conn's syndrome (primary hyperaldosteronism) is characterized by hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis. Metabolic acidosis is not a feature of this condition.
